awd_titl_txt: Exploring Endosymbiont Biodiversity and Complexity in the Family Cicadidae
awd_abstract_narration:
All organisms possess beneficial microbial partners (symbionts) that contribute to their health and survival. Many of these live in the gut and are known as the microbiome. Insect symbionts are theorized to bring new features that allow species formation and habitat invasions. In the case of insects that feed on food lacking important nutrients, highly specialized microbes inhabit organs in the abdomen and provide essential amino acids and vitamins. The major goal of this proposal is to study the interactions between insects and microbes and how they function together in a mutually beneficial relationship. The roles of endosymbionts in speciation and biogeography are largely unexplored and their diversity and evolution is poorly known outside a handful of model systems. This research uses cicadas as a study system because they have a particularly deficient diet and are diverse and spread across the globe. DNA data will be used to construct a dated evolutionary tree to study how the cicadas and their symbiont partners have spread around the world and diversified into new species. This information will be useful in general understanding how microorganisms benefit their hosts and specifically in the study of invasions of beneficial and pest insects of agricultural importance. Biodiversity information for cicadas and their symbionts will be disseminated to scientists and the general public by journal publications, society meetings, and the World Wide Web. Citizen science projects and biology lab exercises will be designed and made available. Future scientists will be trained in multiple laboratories, including one postdoc and two graduate students; many undergraduate participants will interact with scientists internationally via the web. 

Cicada primary endosymbionts have already been demonstrated to include examples of evolution that are surprisingly different from those of other insects, such as rampant symbiont genome duplication/lineage splitting in diverse cicada lineages followed by complementary gene loss and pseudogene formation. To understand the biogeography and evolution of host-symbiont consortia, an existing cicada phylogeny created previously by the research team involved in this work will be expanded and used as a framework. Ecological and symbiont data mapped onto the tree will test hypotheses about the relative timing of changes in cicada habitat association and symbiont consortium membership. This work asks: 1) Does the gain of a secondary (facultative) endosymbiont facilitate the breakdown and or loss of primary (obligate) endosymbiont? Or, 2) Does the breakdown or loss of the obligate endosymbiont allow the invasion of a secondary endosymbiont? Similarly, 3) Do changes in the gut microbiota affect primary endosymbionts (keeping in mind that gut microbiota are known to synthesize essential amino acids for some hosts). Finally, 4) Is symbiont consortium membership related to changes in the external environment (both biotic and abiotic) such as the invasion of new habitats with different environmental conditions and host plants. Improved high-throughput genomic sequencing methods and probes for conserved endosymbiont genes will simultaneously expand the framework Cicadidae evolutionary tree while generating genetic datasets for both of the primary cicada endosymbionts. Surveys of cicada symbiotic partners using metagenomic sequencing (of bacteriomes and fat bodies for endosymbionts) and amplicon sequencing (of gut contents for microbiome studies) will allow the exploration of microbial and fungal symbiont biodiversity. Our hypothesis testing will facilitate exploration of environmental versus evolutionary drivers of biodiversity innovation. New information on the evolution of bacterial endosymbiont genomes will also be produced.

por.por_cntn:
All multicellular organisms including humans are inhabited by a rich variety of symbiotic microbes/fungi essential to the health of the organism. Some of these are required for life (obligate) and others less critical but sometimes useful (facultative). We investigated a symbiont consortium of obligate and facultative microorganisms and asked how they change over time, and how these changes are affected by the environment and the presence/absence of other symbionts. We used cicadas as our study system because they are known to possess two obligate endosymbionts, expected to have facultative microbes, and are found globally. In terms of broader impacts, our study trained both pre- and post-graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. In addition, we reached out to the public in a variety of ways and collaborated with multiple scientific and technical researchers.
We found that the smaller of the two obligate bacterial symbionts had undergone unprecedented splitting and duplication of its genome and that it was sometimes replaced by a fungal symbiont. This splitting emerged multiple times independently throughout the genealogy and worldwide. Splitting was not correlated with fungal replacement. We demonstrated that the fungal symbiont had been acquired many times independently. We also showed that cicada gut microbiome bacteria are not specialized and that different species are acquired from different environments. One collaboration found that fungi that infect cicadas produce medicinal chemicals.
Much of our work, in addition to answering specific evolutionary questions, has implications for the best practices for constructing evolutionary genealogies. Genealogies are used in all disciplines of biology to understand the evolution of characteristics such as cellular physiology, organ systems, development, morphology, and the evolution of disease vectors. In the process we created two new open-source bioinformatics pipelines. Our work contributed 23 scientific publications (four more in progress). These publications are a framework for future work on cicadas (>3000 species globally) and their bacterial and fungal symbionts. Several of our publications contributed to knowledge of the distribution of genetic variability across landscapes.
The Simon lab continues to collaborate with The Museum of Natural History (London), to use shallow genome skims of rare museum specimens to study previously unsampled taxa. We are also collaborating with other UCONN scientists and BYU to sequence the complete genome of periodical cicadas. This work uses a bioinformatics pipeline created as part of an NSF CAREER grant to our UCONN collaborator.
 
Broader Impacts: Diverse Researchers in the Simon Lab included 9 undergraduates (2 visiting), 6 graduate students (3 visiting) and 2 postdocs. Mentoring activities included weekly lab meetings, scientific presentations at local, national and international meetings, multiple workshops, extended visits to other laboratories, field trips, scientific writing, specialized classes, advice on applying to graduate school. Of these 7 Simon-lab undergrads, 3 went on to graduate school, two to medical school, one to environmental policy, one to a career in design. One of our master’s students went on to graduate school and the other to an environmental agency. Two of the three Simon Lab graduate students became postdocs; the third will finish his PhD in 2024, completed a 9-month New Zealand Fulbright fellowship) and has been offered a postdoc.
 
Results from this award were incorporated into undergraduate/graduate teaching. In multiple years, the PI taught a mentoring class using procedures from this NSF award as an example of best practices. One of our Simon Lab undergrads acted as campus coordinator for 4-H "Adventures in STEM" at UCONN for 100 middle and high school students from, underserved, rural areas for hands on learning of basic molecular biology techniques with help from a second Simon Lab undergraduate.
 
Involvement of collaborators located in >13 countries contributed to scientific productivity in those countries. Our work stimulated >25 collaborative projects including with scientists in the areas of evolutionary biology, ecology, systematics, materials science, agriculture, and environmental education. For example, we contributed specimens to a project at the Technical University of Vienna to study the antibacterial and reflective properties of the surface structure of cicada wings and consulted with scientists from Kimberly-Clark working with paper surfaces. We supplied detailed periodical cicada geolocation and timing data to investigate the 2021 mass mortality event in songbirds. We developed protocols for studying the microbiome of cicadas. We have also supported the work of artists and educators. For example, we advised creators of several video documentaries; an exhibit at two science museums; a participatory NPR “Radio Lab” program; a book on insect decline; several children’s book on periodical cicadas, a dance performance and a sculpture exhibition.
 
We used 17-year periodical cicadas as a flagship taxon to educate the public, especially students, on the value of biodiversity to the health of the environment. This was accomplished using the internet (Facebook, Twitter, Cicadamania, Cicadas.uconn.edu, CicadaSafari.com), print and online media (podcasts, newspapers & magazines), television and radio, as well as in-person visits, museum exhibits, and public outreach lectures.
